description: From Middle English warysshen, from Anglo-Norman waris-, the present participle stem of warir, from Old French guarir (modern guérir), from Frankish *warjan, from Proto-Germanic *warjaną. Compare guarish.

verbs.description: warish (third-person singular simple present warishes, present participle warishing, simple past and past participle warished)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To cure or heal (an illness or a person).
examples: Varro testifieth, that even at this day there be some there who warish and cure the stinging of serpents with their spittle.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To get better; to recover from an illness.

adjectives.description: warish (comparative more warish, superlative most warish)

examples: Because we found that operations management, strategic management of war forces, proved to have a lot of value, strategic management was shifted over into the arena of the industrial organization. So you'll notice the definition of strategy comes very much from a warish, militaristic context, i.e., the positioning of armed  forces...
